The Illinois State Board of Education Guidelines released on Monday currently read that all students and staff will be required to wear face coverings while at school. Congratulations to this year’s student award winners from the Class of 2020.

The American Legion Citizenship Awards are selected by teachers. Teachers nominate and vote for students who best represent the character qualities of courage, honor, leadership, patriotism, scholarship and service. A total of 11 students were nominated, and four students received awards: Leah Goldberg and William Soh received Distinguished Achievement Awards, and Anna Gebicz and Euben Ko received Honorable Mention.

Nominees for the award included Andrew Burke, Katie Carpenter, Maddie Noll,
Christina Peters, Will Steele, Yasmeen Taha, and Ben Vishnevskiy.

Hannah Slater received the Northbrook Rotary Volunteer Service Award for extraordinary work in the spirit of volunteerism and the Rotary motto, “Service Above Self.”

Read the full story on graduation posted on our website. https://www.northbrook28.net/news/what_s_new/n_b_j_h_class_of_2020_unique_graduation

Greenbriar School added 10 new photos to the album: Ellis Island — at GreenbriarElementarySchool.
March · Northbrook, IL ·

Four about one hour on Friday, Greenbriar fourth-grade students assumed the roles of Irish, Italian, Polish and Russian immigrants arriving on Ellis Island at the turn of the century. They were crowded into a ‘vessel’ where they watched a documentary about the immigrant experience and were then shepherded through four processing areas, just like the immigration station in New York Harbor.
“We are studying immigration and the push and pull factors for the reasons people immigrated to the United States,” said 4th grade teacher Laura Scott.
“The whole idea is that they came for the American Dream but may not have always
found it,” Mrs. Ellen Feeney said.
Many thanks to the parent volunteers who worked the four 'processing stations:' Currency Exchange, Baggage, Medical and Legal/interview.
One fourth-grade boy was a father from Ireland for the afternoon trying to get through Ellis Island with his father, wife and two daughters. “It showed me that times were hard. But when you get past it you’re very grateful,” he said.

Northbrook District 28 Young Explorers Early Childhood Program is now enrolling students for the AM and PM sessions of fall 2020.

Young Explorers features a blended model to serve students identified as typically developing, at-risk, and in need of special education services. The program is located at Westmoor School and is open to all students who live within District 28 boundaries.

The AM session is for 3- and 4-year-old children. A child can start on his/her 3rd birthday. Parents can register for a screening six months in advance of a child's 3rd birthday.

The PM Session is for children who will turn 5 years old between Sept. 2, 2020 and Sept. 1, 2021.

More details are available on the district website, https://www.northbrook28.net/programs/young_explorers_early_childhood_program

With the help and expertise of 12 fencers from the Glenbrook Fencing Team, the students were shown form and technique for what is considered a ‘conversation’ sport.
“Fencing is a sport about discipline, precision and respect,” said Dr. RJ Gravel, District 225 assistant superintendent of business services, who coaches the team. “It is grounded first and foremost in sportsmanship. There’s lots of eye contact, even though the protective mask, and in each move, you are talking to your opponent with your eyes, then out of nowhere you lunge in for a touch.”
Thanks to the Greenbriar PTO for purchasing the fencing equipment, exposing students to another sport and perhaps a lifelong interest!

post_text: Nineteen NBJH 8th-grade girls participated in the Futures Unlimited program at Oakton Community College and Glenbrook North on Friday. Futures Unlimited provides insight and encouragement for girls who are interested in pursuing careers in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math fields. NBJH Girls participated in two sessions at Oakton. The first delved into the practical applications of chemistry--students created functional batteries from a combination of chemical solutions and tested their voltage. The second provided a hands-on introduction to probability where girls used statistical equations to determine the likelihood of choosing a given color M&M from a particular bag. Later, students visited GBN where they worked with high school students in Intro to Design and Engineering to complete 3D modeling. Students finished the day with a tour of the classrooms and facilities where GBN's many STEM electives are taught. #28Empowers
